Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Effects of immune gene diversity on immune function and survival in an endangered bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
The increasing emergence and spread of pathogens are serious concerns for both human and wildlife populations. The threat is substantially greater for populations of endangered species because they often have reduced genetic diversity, which could impair immune function and increase their susceptibility to disease. However, to date no studies have directly examined diversity at immune genes and their relationship to both disease resistance and survival. In greater prairie-chickens, we previously found that diversity at a variety of immune genes was reduced in small populations, but it remains unclear how that will affect individuals. The current study will extend that research and specifically examine how immune gene diversity in individuals is related to their immune function and survival in the wild. Thus, the results from this study will provide a broader understanding of the importance of immune gene diversity to individual survival and ultimately entire populations.

The Attwater?s prairie-chicken is one of the most endangered birds in North America. The persistence of the remaining wild population relies entirely on a large captive breeding and release program in Texas. About 200 captive-bred juveniles are released each year, but 79% of them die within nine months. It is known that outbred individuals have greater survival, but previous work showed no relationship between genome-wide genetic diversity and four immunological assays for pathogen resistance. The intense captive breeding and release program provides an unparalleled opportunity to study how diversity at immune genes directly influences immune function and survival. This study will characterize immune gene diversity across a wide array of immune genes (encompassing both innate and acquired immunity) in prairie-chickens and correlate it with data on immune function and survival already obtained from previously released birds. The results from this study will provide a broader understanding of the links between immune genes and survival, and, therefore, help managers make informed decisions about which individuals to pair for breeding or release into the wild.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The increasing emergence and spread of pathogens through wildlife populations are serious concerns for both wildlife and humans. The threat is substantially greater for populations of endangered species because they often have reduced genetic diversity, which could impair immune function and increase their susceptibility to disease. However, few studies have directly examined diversity at immune genes and their relationship to both disease resistance and survival. The captive breeding and release program in Texas for the endangered Attwater's prairie-chicken provides a rare opportunity to study this relationship.  Each year about 200 captive-bred juveniles are released into the wild to help maintain the wild population of about 210 adults, but 79% of the released birds die within nine months. Previously, we found that genetic diversity was reduced in this small population, but it was unclear how low genetic diversity might affect the resistance of individuals to disease and their subsequent survival. To address this issue, we examined genetic diversity and correlated it with data on immune function and survival.

We found that survival of released birds was related to specific variants of immune genes (toll-like and MHC receptors), and not to overall genetic variation across the genome. We also found that some measures of immune response at the time of release were related to variants of these immune genes, and not to overall genomic variation. The intensive management and daily monitoring of released Attwater’s prairie-chickens gave us detailed estimates of individual survival that are rarely found in other studies, except in fish hatcheries or in populations where dispersal events are very limited (e.g., isolated islands). Our discovery of associations between particular genes and both immunity and survival provides an important step in genetic rescue efforts to help increase survival rates of released birds and to increase the size of this endangered population. 

 

Broader Impacts

These results were published in a paper in the journal Molecular Ecology with co-PI Zachary Bateson as first author (Bateson et al. 2016. DOI: 10.1111/mec.13793). PI Dunn also presented these (and related results) at the North American Ornithological Conference in Washington DC, (Aug 2016) at a special symposium "Current and Future Prospects on Avian De-Extinction and Genetic Rescue", and at the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology conference in New Orleans (Jan 2017). The new methods of genomic analysis that we used in the project provided training for co-PI Bateson, which helped him obtain a position as a research scientist at the National Agricultural Genotyping Laboratory in North Dakota.  The project also led to stronger collaborations between PI Dunn and researchers at the University of North Texas, the Attwater Prairie Chicken National Wildlife refuge and the University of Lodz (Poland). Our genomic data have been deposited in Genbank for others to use in comparative studies, and we will be continuing to explore the data for particular genes associated with immunity and survival.
